meanings.definition: To arrange again in a different order.
meanings.sent1: I need to reorder the books on the shelf by size.
meanings.sent2: She decided to reorder the numbers from smallest to largest.
meanings.sent3: After the wind blew them around, I had to reorder the scattered papers.
meanings.sent4: Her mind was a jumble of thoughts that needed to be reordered like a messy room.
meanings.sent5: The puzzle pieces were mixed up, so I had to reorder them to complete the picture.

meanings.definition: To request more of something that has already been ordered.
meanings.sent1: I will reorder more supplies for the office next week.
meanings.sent2: He had to reorder more copies of the book due to high demand.
meanings.sent3: The hungry customers had to reorder their favorite dish as they finished it quickly.
meanings.sent4: The flowers were so beautiful that she had to reorder them for another event.
meanings.sent5: The popular item sold out fast, prompting customers to reorder it online.

meanings.definition: To put things back in their correct or original order.
meanings.sent1: Please reorder the books on the shelf alphabetically.
meanings.sent2: The librarian had to reorder the misplaced books on the shelves.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous child tried to reorder the items on the teacher's desk as a prank.
meanings.sent4: The chaos of the room needed to be reordered into a tidy space.
meanings.sent5: The artist had to reorder the colors on the palette to match the original painting.
